bestBHT.bht: Those who reject or despise the limitations and rules set by God are rejecting the very nature of God Himself, the one who has given them His Holy Spirit. These commands are not mere human instructions, but divine mandates communicated by the Spirit of God. Believers have been bestowed with the Holy Spirit so that they can reflect the holiness of God. Disregarding these commands is not to be taken lightly, as it signifies a rejection of God's authority and a disregard for the precious gift of the Holy Spirit bestowed upon believers.

Henry Alford: Hence, the sin of (rejecting) setting at nought such limitations and rules is a fearful one—no less than that of setting at nought God the giver of the Holy Spirit.

There is no need to supply any thing after despiseth: he that despiseth simply describes him who commits the act of despising, the despiser—what he despises, is not to be supplied in the construction, but is clear from the context—viz. his brother.
gave—not giveth—once for all, as being one great definite act of God by his Son. his Spirit, which is holy
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: He who despiseth" or "rejecteth" these our ministerial precepts. (100 words)
His own Spirit, the Holy (One)"; thus emphatically marking "holiness" as the end for which the Holy (One) is being given. (96 words)
As He gives you that which is essentially identical with Himself, He expects you should become like Himself." (97 words)
Albert Barnes: He who disregards such commands as these which call him to a holy life, is really rejecting and disobeying God.
The apostle assures them in the most solemn manner, that, though communicated to them by man, yet they were really the commands of God.
Paul did not give these commands as his own, but as taught by the Spirit of God.
Marvin Vincent: Used in N. T. both of persons and things."
His Holy Spirit [το πνευμα αυτου το αγιον]. Solemn and emphatic: His Spirit, the holy.
John Calvin: He reminds them that they had been endowed with the Spirit of God, first, in order that they may distinguish what proceeds from God.
With heavenly authority, they may pronounce judgment against all manner of unchastity.
Those that are endowed with the Spirit of God have a very different testimony sealed upon their hearts.
Philip Schaff: He that rejecteth, i.e. he who contemptuously or negligently refuses to listen to these injunctions and warnings.
Not man... they contemn not men but God.
The fact that to all believers God gives the Holy Spirit, should both encourage them to persevere in seeking holiness, and should deter them from such sins as are specially offensive to the Spirit.
Archibald T. Robertson: Therefore (τοιγαρουν). This old triple compound particle (τοι, γαρ, ουν) is in the N.T. only here and Hebrews 12:1. Paul applies the logic of the case.
He that rejecteth (ο αθετων). This late verb (Polybius and LXX) is from α-θετος (α privative and verbal of τιθημ, to proscribe a thing, to annul it.
But God (αλλα τον θεον). Paul sees this clearly and modern atheists see it also. In order to justify their licentiousness they do not hesitate to set aside God.
John Gill: By despising these exhortations, they themselves were despised, though not alone: but God.
To slight [the commandments], was to slight Jesus Christ himself.
Despising [the apostles' exhortations] was despising the Spirit of God that spake by them.
John Wesley: He that despiseth — The commandments we gave. Despiseth God — Himself."
Who hath also given you his Holy Spirit — To convince you of the truth, and enable you to be holy."
What naked majesty of words! How oratorical, and yet with what great simplicity!

bhtAttempts.bht: He who despises the limitations and rules set by God, rejects not only the Holy Spirit but also God Himself. The commands given to believers are not mere human instructions, but divine mandates taught by the Spirit of God. God, in His holiness, has endowed believers with His Spirit, expecting them to reflect His likeness and to pursue holiness. Therefore, those who disregard these commandments not only disregard the apostles but also the Spirit of God Himself. Such an act of despising God's commands is not to be taken lightly. It is both a rejection of God's authority and a disregard for the great gift of the Holy Spirit given to believers. So let us be mindful and obedient to God's instructions, recognizing that our rejection of His commandments is a rejection of God Himself.

He who despises the limitations and rules set by God, rejects not only the Holy Spirit but also God Himself. The commands given to believers are divine mandates taught by the Spirit of God. God has endowed believers with his Spirit, expecting them to reflect His likeness and pursue holiness. Therefore, those who disregard these commands disregard the apostles and the Spirit of God. It is a rejection of God's authority and a disregard for the great gift of the Holy Spirit.

He who rejects or despises the limitations and rules set by God is, in essence, rejecting God Himself, the giver of the Holy Spirit. These commands are not human instructions, but divine mandates taught by the Spirit of God. Believers are endowed with the Holy Spirit to become like God and pursue holiness. Disregarding these commands is not taken lightly, as it is a rejection of God's authority and a disregard for the precious gift of the Holy Spirit given to believers.

Those who reject or despise the limitations and rules set by God are rejecting the very nature of God Himself, the one who has given them His Holy Spirit. These commands are not mere human instructions, but divine mandates communicated by the Spirit of God. Believers have been bestowed with the Holy Spirit so that they can reflect the holiness of God. Disregarding these commands is not to be taken lightly, as it signifies a rejection of God's authority and a disregard for the precious gift of the Holy Spirit bestowed upon believers.

To reject or despise the limitations and rules set by God is to reject God Himself and the Holy Spirit He has given. These commands are not ordinary human instructions, but divine mandates delivered by the Spirit of God. Believers have been graced with the Holy Spirit to become like God and pursue holiness. Disregarding these commands is a grave offense, as it disregards God's authority and disregards the tremendous gift of the Holy Spirit bestowed upon believers.
